title: Market Highlights: Sensex settles 316 pts higher, Nifty above 25,550; NTPC rises 3%, L&T 2%
content:
Sensex Today | Nifty 50 | Stock Market Live Updates: India's heartbeat indices rebounded from day's lows to finish the session on a high note. In a volatile session, IT stocks were major laggards, though broad-based buying trends held the markets firm.

US President Donald Trump preempted the official release of GDP figures on Friday, saying that a record-long government shutdown last year had slowed growth by at least two points.

"The Democrat Shutdown cost the U.S.A. at least two points in GDP. That's why they are doing it, in mini form, again," he wrote on Truth Social about a half-hour before the Commerce Department releases it fourth quarter and 2025 full-year growth estimates.

The government is currently in a partial shutdown, only impacting the Department of Homeland Security.

European stocks rebounded and oil prices fell Friday as investors reassessed the chances of a US strike on Iran, after heightened geopolitical tensions sparked by President Donald Trump's threats amid talks on a nuclear deal.

It followed a weak session in Asia, where several markets remained closed for the Lunar New Year break.

Crude prices pulled back after climbing to six-month highs this week on worries that nuclear talks between the United States and oil-rich Iran might not avert a new conflict that could threaten supplies.

"Threats of military action against Iran from the Trump administration... created some jitters in the market yesterday -- with selling in US stocks being matched in most Asian markets," said AJ Bell investment director Russ Mould.

Trump warned Thursday that Tehran should make a "meaningful deal" in negotiations with Washington in the next 10 days or else "bad things happen".

Britain's FTSE indexes gained on Friday and were set to end the week higher, led by ‌defence stocks, while ⁠expectations for ⁠a March rate cut from the Bank of England and easing AI-disruption worries globally also aided sentiment.

The blue-chip ​FTSE 100 was up 0.6% at around 1134 GMT and was trading just shy of a record ​high, while the domestically focused FTSE 250 rose 0.5%.

Geopolitical tensions between Iran and the U.S. and the greater likelihood of defence cooperation within Europe helped defence stocks gain 6% this ​week.

- Vinod Nair, Head of Research at Geojit Investments

The NSE will levy an extra 15% margin on 18 F&O stocks starting March 2026, focusing on securities where top clients account for over 20% of the market-wide position limit. The move is aimed at curbing risks from excessive leverage, while margins on gold and silver futures have been relaxed. Read more

- Dr. VK Vijayakumar, Chief Investment Strategist, Geojit Investments

Europe’s richest individuals are once again allocating capital to hedge fund-style strategies, aiming to capture the industry’s strong returns after years of growing personal wealth.

The bond market’s expectation that the Federal Reserve will deliver at least two more rate cuts this year clashes with the strength of the US economy, according to portfolio managers at Invesco and Carmignac, who say they are positioning against US Treasuries.

Bajaj Finserv’s alternative investment arm is planning to raise up to $1 billion, as it looks to expand beyond its core businesses of lending, mutual funds, and insurance into non-traditional asset classes, a senior group executive told The Economic Times.

Shares of oil exploration companies advanced in an otherwise weak market on Thursday as renewed geopolitical tensions between the United States and Iran heightened fears of supply disruptions and lifted crude prices. Oil India jumped 5.2%, while ONGC rose 3.6%, tracking gains in Brent crude. In contrast, oil marketing firms came under pressure, with HPCL slipping nearly 5% and Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd (BPCL) declining 3.4%.

Overseas investors channelled their biggest allocations into capital goods, financials, and oil & gas stocks in the first half of February, investing ₹33,487 crore across 15 sectors — marking their highest fortnightly inflows since the second half of April 2025.

Indian equity indices tumbled on Thursday, pressured by a renewed flare-up between the United States and Iran that pushed Brent crude above $71 a barrel, highlighting the oil-import-reliant economy’s sensitivity to rising energy costs amid a gradual weakening of the rupee against the US dollar over the past year.

Oil prices rose on Friday as concerns over a potential conflict between the U.S. and Iran intensified, after Washington warned that Tehran would face consequences if it failed to reach an agreement on its nuclear programme within days.

The dollar was on track Friday to post its strongest weekly gain since October, supported by a string of stronger-than-expected economic data, a more hawkish outlook from the Federal Reserve, and heightened tensions between the U.S. and Iran that kept markets cautious.

Nvidia and Apple weighed on sentiment as Wall Street closed lower on Thursday, with declines in private equity firms adding pressure, while earnings-led strength in industrial stocks helped cap the overall losses.

Asian equities declined as rising tensions in Iran dampened investor sentiment, while oil prices climbed to their highest level since August.

In today’s trade, shares of Federal Bank, Waaree Energies, ICICI Prudential Life Insurance, Zydus Lifesciences, and Hindustan Unilever, among others, are likely to remain in focus amid various news-driven developments and corporate updates.
